some of you might need this. Characters
in Unreal, as we might know, are very
different than other tools. And then
that throws a lot of people off,
especially animators. It's not just like
a model that gets a rig and then that is
your asset and you bring in your
character with your modeled your rigged
model and then you go. There's like a
whole ecosystem of how these things work
together. At the core level, the
skeleton is the thing that determines
whether what you're trying to do is
going to work with the other thing
you're trying to do it with. So, if
you've got a character and you've got
motion capture or a rig somewhere that
you're like, can I connect these things?
The skeleton is what determines whether
those things are compatible with one
another at a super super high level. And
then the skeletal mesh or the blueprint,
depending on how complex your character
is, is probably the thing you're going
to drag and drop to like use that
character. The skeletal mesh is
basically just the character with the
bones inside. It's all skinned. It
works. It may not be a rig attached to
it, but that's the thing you need to
move forward. Metahumans are blueprints,
as an example. There are a lot more
pieces to them, and so they're
constructed. They're like, it's like an
after effects, if you know that one.
It's like a pre-omposition of other
things. I don't know.

one is just a level sequence. That's
sort of the core of what every animator
is always looking for. Like how do I
like work in Unreal? You want a level
sequence. That's like your animation
file. And that's also your shot file for

One of the things that happens in Unreal
is the engine will go as fast as it can
to evaluate the frames. But when you're
watching it back, sometimes even if
you're set to 24 fps or something, your
viewport will give you more frames than
that actual number. And if you get weird
artifacts, you can you can lock the
viewport with that C bar to only give
you 24 fps on your screen. So you get a
better representation of what the actual
render is going to look like. Doesn't
really account for motion blur, but that
sometimes happens in other examples
you'll see later.

specifically, you have to click the plus

always like to set a key on the first
one. You just copy all this data and

top of itself. And you can continue to
